definition: to welcome/to meet/to face/to forge ahead (esp. in the face of difficulties)
to receive/to answer (the phone)/to meet or welcome sb/to connect/to catch/to join/to extend/to take one's turn on duty/to take over for sb
to carry on a shoulder pole/to choose/to pick/to nitpick
to raise/to dig up/to poke/to prick/to incite/to stir up

sentences.english: We have taken on a task that will be difficult, but the people of the Empire are ready for the challenge.
sentences.chinese: 任重而道遠，但帝國的子民們已做好迎接挑戰的準備。

sentences.english: Measures should be taken pertinently to receive challenges.
sentences.chinese: 應有針對性地採取措施，迎接挑戰。

sentences.english: But I also believe that we cannot lose the opportunity to meet this challenge.
sentences.chinese: 但我也想深我們不能錯過這個迎接挑戰的機會。

sentences.english: The School of Fine Arts of Chengdu University will grasp the opportunities and face the challenges to create fruitful future again.
sentences.chinese: 成都大學美術學院將抓住機遇，迎接挑戰，再創輝煌。

sentences.english: Receive Challenge, Serve "Agriculture, Countryside and Peasant", Develop the Self-study Examination of High Education Steadily.
sentences.chinese: 迎接挑戰，服務三農，穩步發展高教自考。

sentences.english: We choose to deal with challenges now rather than leaving them for future generations.
sentences.chinese: 我們選擇現在迎接挑戰而非將其留給後代。

sentences.english: The question is whether leaders can cooperate in steering these changes.
sentences.chinese: 現在的問題是，各國領導人能否精誠合作，迎接挑戰。

sentences.english: Meet the challenge, and make a break-through.
sentences.chinese: 迎接挑戰，纔能有所突破。

sentences.english: Ericsson is looking forward to meet the challenges and win the future together with Cable & Media customers.
sentences.chinese: 愛立信希望和廣電客戶一起攜手迎接挑戰，同創未來。

sentences.english: The question is whether leaders can cooperate in steering the changes.
sentences.chinese: 現在的問題是，各國領導人能否團結合作，迎接挑戰。

definition: (abbr. for 嘗試錯誤|尝试错误) trial and error/failure
to tackle a thorny problem and overcome its challenges
highest common factor HCF/greatest common divisor GCD
benevolent heart and skillful execution (idiom, from Mencius); charitable in thought and deed
to be at the highest level of enlightenment (Buddhist expression)
to follow through/to carry through to the end
